3:40, that stupid monk

Hey, Vsauce. Michael here. The title of this video is misspelled in honor of mistakes. Mistakes are everywhere, they surround us like air. To err is human. Faults, flaws, faux pas, fumbles and fallacies are as much a part of who we are today as the stuff we've gotten right. For instance, if a knight knocked your knuckle or knifed your knee, why would there be so many "k"s? Well, the "k"s are silent by mistake. The original old English forms of these words were pronounced with "k" sounds. K-nife, k-night, k-nee. But that's a bit of a mouthful to say and because reading and writing weren't as common hundreds of years ago, people just pronounced words the way they want to do, regardless of spelling. Spelling is fun. Warren G knows what I'm talking about. In the fourth verse of his "What's Next", he asks what's next. What's next, what's N-X-E-T. Spelling isn't the only thing we get wrong. The history of science is a graveyard of dead an abandoned ideas. Fritz Machlup coined the phrase "Half-life of knowledge". The amount of time it takes for half of the knowledge within a field to be superseded by new, better ideas or to simply be shown untrue. Donald Hebb famously estimated that the half-life of knowledge in psychology is just five years. Humans are awesome, don't get me wrong, but we tend to believe that what we currently think we know about the universe is reasonably correct, even though statistics aren't on our side. Previous generations incorrectly thought the exact same thing about what they used to think was true. My favorite examples of the ubiquity of mistakes are production errors in popular songs. They're like humbling Easter eggs, just waiting to be found. For instance, Buffalo Springfield's "For What It's Worth". 26 seconds in the "be" in the lyric "beware" is clipped, as is the "p" in "people" at 1:24 minute. Once you hear the mistake, it's tough to unhear it. In "Hey Jude" Paul McCartney misses a cord. And if you listen closely you can clearly hear him say "F**ing hll". Seriously, it's in the actual song. Go listen to it. In fact, there's an entire website that chronicles mistakes in Beatles' songs. Take a look at this 700-year-old prayer book. A monk wrote it on fresh, clean paper. I'm kidding, of course. He scraped the ink off an older manuscript, cut the pages and rotated them before writing all over them. A mistake? Well, kind of. Recent multispectral images of the prayer book have revealed that the old manuscript he erased was a previously unknown copy of a work by Archimedes. It was called "The Method" and laid out the heart of calculus thousands of years before Newton and Leibniz. If that one monk hadn't erased that one book, would we be hundreds, thousands of years mathematically and technologically more advanced today than we currently are? It's hard to say. All that is certain is that we would continue to make ridiculous mistakes, like the Mars Climate Orbiter. This 327.6 million dollar expedition burned up in the red planet's atmosphere because when calculating flight maneuvers NASA used the agreed-upon metric units while Lockheed Martin used the imperial system. This is Neil Armstrong taking humankind's first steps on the Moon. It's about the best footage we have. The original tapes containing the highest quality recording of that moment have been lost. They were probably recorded over by later test missions. Ten years ago Sergio Martinez became lost in the woods while hunting outside of San Diego. Hoping to attract the attention of rescuers, he lit a small fire. But that fire quickly got out of control and became a giant Cedar Fire. It destroyed 300,000 acres of land, 2,322 homes and killed 15 people. The man carrying a wounded soldier in this painting, based on a photograph taken during World War I, is Henry Tandey, an English recipient of the Victoria Cross. Four years after the event in this image Tandey caught a wounded German soldier in his gun sights. But rather than kill the man, Tandey took pity on his wounded state and spared his life. The German he allowed to live was this man. Later the man whose life he spared wore his mustache shorter but still had the same name, Adolf Hitler. In 1918 did Henry Tandey miss a chance to kill Hitler? Detailed researchers found that the exact days their units were in the same location don't quite match up. The story is apocryphal but what is known is that Hitler owned a copy of the painting of Tandey, and in 1938, when meeting with Neville Chamberlain, Hitler pointed to Tandey and told Chamberlain: "That man came so close to killing me in 1918 that I thought I should never see Germany again." So, who's wrong? Maybe Hitler confirmed the story merely because he hoped to make up extra evidence that providence had kept him alive to pursue his goals. Either way, someone is mistaken. Missed opportunities are a bummer. Obsessing over them is not healthy but regret is a powerful emotion. How do you deal with regret, with guilt? Can you? In the early morning hours on a bench outside a hotel in Anaheim this summer Ze Frank told me something I am going to paraphrase. I love this metaphor. Stuff in your past is like a carving on the bark of sapling. Over time, the scar, the carving won't go away. Because of the way trees grow it won't go up or down much either, it'll just stay right where it began. It might even get darker. But it won't get bigger. You, however, can. You can keep growing, doing more things, more branches, being more things. The wound won't get smaller but you can make it a smaller part of who you are. Maybe regrets are like that. They stick around forever like arborglyphs. Or maybe they make like a tree and leaf. A red or purple leaf in the autumn. As days get shorter and chlorophyll production decreases, the yellow and orange carotenoids, which are always in leaves, appear as the green fades. But red and purple leaves are the interesting ones. As winter approaches it would seem to be a good time for trees to conserve energy but some trees do the opposite. Instead of giving up, they spend extra energy producing anthocyanins to turn their leaves red and purple hues. These colors protect their leaves from sun damage before their nutrients can all be used and may also be a defense against insects looking for a parasitic home. A way for the tree to tell the insects: "Yes, I am in part dying but not without a fight. I am still very much vital." Drought and even tourniquets applied by man can bring about these colors prematurely. When you look at beautiful autumn colors, you are looking at stress. But the bigger the fight the trees put up, the more energy they put into their defenses at the very end, the more brilliant their colors will be. Winter will eventually come. But scientifically, the brightest, deepest, most remarkable colors come from not giving up too easily or quickly. And as always, thanks for watching.

The new WORDS I learned from this video as an English Learner :

err be mistaken or incorrect; make a mistake
faux pas an embarrassing or tactless act or remark in a social situation
tact·less having or showing a lack of skill and sensitivity in dealing with others or with difficult issues
fum·ble do or handle something clumsily
fal·lacy a mistaken belief, especially one based on unsound arguments
super·sede take the place of (a person or thing previously in authority or use); supplant
stat·is·tics facts · figures · details · particulars · specifics · features · information
ubi·quity the fact of appearing everywhere or of being very common
hum·ble cause (someone) to feel less important or proud
scrape rake · drag · push · brush · sweep
manu·script a book, document, or piece of music written by hand rather than typed or printed
multi·spec·tral operating in or involving several regions of the electromagnetic spectrum
re·cipi·ent a person or thing that receives or is awarded something:
apoc·ryph·al (of a story or statement) of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true:
merely only
para·phrase express the meaning of (something written or spoken) using different words, especially to achieve greater clarity:
sap·ling a young tree, especially one with a slender trunk
meta·phor a figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable:
con·serve protect (something, especially something of environmental or cultural importance) from harm or destruction

With regard to the monk who scraped the ink off of the manuscript containing important results in calculus, Michael Stevens should read about the Kerala School of Astronomy and Mathematics. Mathematicians in this school also (independently) produced important results in calculus long before Newton and Leibniz, and these results similarly led nowhere. History is probably full of examples of world-changing discoveries that had to be discovered several times before they changed the world. Maybe we should honor the monk who vandalized the manuscript for bringing us that much closer to meeting the number of instances of f$&@ing things up that the Universe demands before letting us make progress.

There's a lot of this in music.  Sometimes they are left in on purpose but realistically, the older songs took a lot more effort to make with analog machines in which they had to physically cut the tapes of audio and place them exactly to record the song.  Or the first few recordings that had to be mass produced by recording each physical unit they planned to sell, they eventually started the concept of Master tracks where all tracks where made from the original composition/recording which brings forth the term "Masters".  On Jay Z's "Magna Carta Holy Grail" Album, you can hear his chains clinking together, which is normally a "no-no" by engineering standards but I believe it was left in as a commentary on his affluent status and as a reference to the debate about young rappers wearing jewelry vs very wealthy people not wearing jewelry.  Jay Z is a rapper who no longer is seen wearing jewelry as often as he used to but he wore his jewelry while recording in contrast to what you normally see him wear in more recent times.

When my dad was a kid he would often visit a lake. Once while he was there he saw someone boat over to one of the various small islands. The person lit a campfire, but put it too close to some bushes. The resulting fire burned away every single tree and plant on the island. From then on, my dad gave island the fitting name "Bald Rock"

Now, 50 years later, that island still has noticeably younger trees than the others. Crazy that it is all because of someone making a single mistake.

Hey, Vsauce. Michael here. The title of this video is misspelled in honor of mistakes. Mistakes are everywhere, they surround us like air. To err is human. Faults, flaws, faux pas, fumbles and fallacies are as much a part of who we are today as the stuff we've gotten right. For instance, if a knight knocked your knuckle or knifed your knee, why would there be so many "k"s? Well, the "k"s are silent by mistake. The original old English forms of these words were pronounced with "k" sounds. K-nife, k-night, k-nee. But that's a bit of a mouthful to say and because reading and writing weren't as common hundreds of years ago, people just pronounced words the way they want to do, regardless of spelling. Spelling is fun. Warren G knows what I'm talking about. In the fourth verse of his "What's Next", he asks what's next. What's next, what's N-X-E-T. Spelling isn't the only thing we get wrong. The history of science is a graveyard of dead an abandoned ideas. Fritz Machlup coined the phrase "Half-life of knowledge". The amount of time it takes for half of the knowledge within a field to be superseded by new, better ideas or to simply be shown untrue. Donald Hebb famously estimated that the half-life of knowledge in psychology is just five years. Humans are awesome, don't get me wrong, but we tend to believe that what we currently think we know about the universe is reasonably correct, even though statistics aren't on our side. Previous generations incorrectly thought the exact same thing about what they used to think was true. My favorite examples of the ubiquity of mistakes are production errors in popular songs. They're like humbling Easter eggs, just waiting to be found. For instance, Buffalo Springfield's "For What It's Worth". 26 seconds in the "be" in the lyric "beware" is clipped, as is the "p" in "people" at 1:24 minute. Once you hear the mistake, it's tough to unhear it. In "Hey Jude" Paul McCartney misses a chord. And if you listen closely you can clearly hear him say "F**ing hll". Seriously, it's in the actual song. Go listen to it. In fact, there's an entire website that chronicles mistakes in Beatles' songs. Take a look at this 700-year-old prayer book. A monk wrote it on fresh, clean paper. I'm kidding, of course. He scraped the ink off an older manuscript, cut the pages and rotated them before writing all over them. A mistake? Well, kind of. Recent multispectral images of the prayer book have revealed that the old manuscript he erased was a previously unknown copy of a work by Archimedes. It was called "The Method" and laid out the heart of calculus thousands of years before Newton and Leibniz. If that one monk hadn't erased that one book, would we be hundreds, thousands of years mathematically and technologically more advanced today than we currently are? It's hard to say. All that is certain is that we would continue to make ridiculous mistakes, like the Mars Climate Orbiter. This 327.6 million dollar expedition burned up in the red planet's atmosphere because when calculating flight maneuvers NASA used the agreed-upon metric units while Lockheed Martin used the imperial system. This is Neil Armstrong taking humankind's first steps on the Moon. It's about the best footage we have. The original tapes containing the highest quality recording of that moment have been lost. They were probably recorded over by later test missions. Ten years ago Sergio Martinez became lost in the woods while hunting outside of San Diego. Hoping to attract the attention of rescuers, he lit a small fire. But that fire quickly got out of control and became a giant Cedar Fire. It destroyed 300,000 acres of land, 2,322 homes and killed 15 people. The man carrying a wounded soldier in this painting, based on a photograph taken during World War I, is Henry Tandey, an English recipient of the Victoria Cross. Four years after the event in this image Tandey caught a wounded German soldier in his gun sights. But rather than kill the man, Tandey took pity on his wounded state and spared his life. The German he allowed to live was this man. Later the man whose life he spared wore his mustache shorter but still had the same name, Adolf Hitler. In 1918 did Henry Tandey miss a chance to kill Hitler? Detailed researchers found that the exact days their units were in the same location don't quite match up. The story is apocryphal but what is known is that Hitler owned a copy of the painting of Tandey, and in 1938, when meeting with Neville Chamberlain, Hitler pointed to Tandey and told Chamberlain: "That man came so close to killing me in 1918 that I thought I should never see Germany again." So, who's wrong? Maybe Hitler confirmed the story merely because he hoped to make up extra evidence that providence had kept him alive to pursue his goals. Either way, someone is mistaken. Missed opportunities are a bummer. Obsessing over them is not healthy but regret is a powerful emotion. How do you deal with regret, with guilt? Can you? In the early morning hours on a bench outside a hotel in Anaheim this summer Ze Frank told me something I am going to paraphrase. I love this metaphor. Stuff in your past is like a carving on the bark of sapling. Over time, the scar, the carving won't go away. Because of the way trees grow it won't go up or down much either, it'll just stay right where it began. It might even get darker. But it won't get bigger. You, however, can. You can keep growing, doing more things, more branches, being more things. The wound won't get smaller but you can make it a smaller part of who you are. Maybe regrets are like that. They stick around forever like arborglyphs. Or maybe they make like a tree and leaf. A red or purple leaf in the autumn. As days get shorter and chlorophyll production decreases, the yellow and orange carotenoids, which are always in leaves, appear as the green fades. But red and purple leaves are the interesting ones. As winter approaches it would seem to be a good time for trees to conserve energy but some trees do the opposite. Instead of giving up, they spend extra energy producing anthocyanins to turn their leaves red and purple hues. These colors protect their leaves from sun damage before their nutrients can all be used and may also be a defense against insects looking for a parasitic home. A way for the tree to tell the insects: "Yes, I am in part dying but not without a fight. I am still very much vital." Drought and even tourniquets applied by man can bring about these colors prematurely. When you look at beautiful autumn colors, you are looking at stress. But the bigger the fight the trees put up, the more energy they put into their defenses at the very end, the more brilliant their colors will be. Winter will eventually come. But scientifically, the brightest, deepest, most remarkable colors come from not giving up too easily or quickly. And as always, thanks for watching.

Hey, Vsauce. Michael here. The title of this video is misspelled in honor of mistakes. Mistakes are everywhere, they surround us like air. To err is human. Faults, flaws, faux pas, fumbles and fallacies are as much a part of who we are today as the stuff we've gotten right. For instance, if a knight knocked your knuckle or knifed your knee, why would there be so many "k"s? Well, the "k"s are silent by mistake. The original old English forms of these words were pronounced with "k" sounds. K-nife, k-night, k-nee. But that's a bit of a mouthful to say and because reading and writing weren't as common hundreds of years ago, people just pronounced words the way they want to do, regardless of spelling. Spelling is fun. Warren G knows what I'm talking about. In the fourth verse of his "What's Next", he asks what's next. What's next, what's N-X-E-T. Spelling isn't the only thing we get wrong. The history of science is a graveyard of dead an abandoned ideas. Fritz Machlup coined the phrase "Half-life of knowledge". The amount of time it takes for half of the knowledge within a field to be superseded by new, better ideas or to simply be shown untrue. Donald Hebb famously estimated that the half-life of knowledge in psychology is just five years. Humans are awesome, don't get me wrong, but we tend to believe that what we currently think we know about the universe is reasonably correct, even though statistics aren't on our side. Previous generations incorrectly thought the exact same thing about what they used to think was true. My favorite examples of the ubiquity of mistakes are production errors in popular songs. They're like humbling Easter eggs, just waiting to be found. For instance, Buffalo Springfield's "For What It's Worth". 26 seconds in the "be" in the lyric "beware" is clipped, as is the "p" in "people" at 1:24 minute. Once you hear the mistake, it's tough to unhear it. In "Hey Jude" Paul McCartney misses a chord. And if you listen closely you can clearly hear him say "F**ing hll". Seriously, it's in the actual song. Go listen to it. In fact, there's an entire website that chronicles mistakes in Beatles' songs. Take a look at this 700-year-old prayer book. A monk wrote it on fresh, clean paper. I'm kidding, of course. He scraped the ink off an older manuscript, cut the pages and rotated them before writing all over them. A mistake? Well, kind of. Recent multispectral images of the prayer book have revealed that the old manuscript he erased was a previously unknown copy of a work by Archimedes. It was called "The Method" and laid out the heart of calculus thousands of years before Newton and Leibniz. If that one monk hadn't erased that one book, would we be hundreds, thousands of years mathematically and technologically more advanced today than we currently are? It's hard to say. All that is certain is that we would continue to make ridiculous mistakes, like the Mars Climate Orbiter. This 327.6 million dollar expedition burned up in the red planet's atmosphere because when calculating flight maneuvers NASA used the agreed-upon metric units while Lockheed Martin used the imperial system. This is Neil Armstrong taking humankind's first steps on the Moon. It's about the best footage we have. The original tapes containing the highest quality recording of that moment have been lost. They were probably recorded over by later test missions. Ten years ago Sergio Martinez became lost in the woods while hunting outside of San Diego. Hoping to attract the attention of rescuers, he lit a small fire. But that fire quickly got out of control and became a giant Cedar Fire. It destroyed 300,000 acres of land, 2,322 homes and killed 15 people. The man carrying a wounded soldier in this painting, based on a photograph taken during World War I, is Henry Tandey, an English recipient of the Victoria Cross. Four years after the event in this image Tandey caught a wounded German soldier in his gun sights. But rather than kill the man, Tandey took pity on his wounded state and spared his life. The German he allowed to live was this man. Later the man whose life he spared wore his mustache shorter but still had the same name, Adolf Hitler. In 1918 did Henry Tandey miss a chance to kill Hitler? Detailed researchers found that the exact days their units were in the same location don't quite match up. The story is apocryphal but what is known is that Hitler owned a copy of the painting of Tandey, and in 1938, when meeting with Neville Chamberlain, Hitler pointed to Tandey and told Chamberlain: "That man came so close to killing me in 1918 that I thought I should never see Germany again." So, who's wrong? Maybe Hitler confirmed the story merely because he hoped to make up extra evidence that providence had kept him alive to pursue his goals. Either way, someone is mistaken. Missed opportunities are a bummer. Obsessing over them is not healthy but regret is a powerful emotion. How do you deal with regret, with guilt? Can you? In the early morning hours on a bench outside a hotel in Anaheim this summer Ze Frank told me something I am going to paraphrase. I love this metaphor. Stuff in your past is like a carving on the bark of sapling. Over time, the scar, the carving won't go away. Because of the way trees grow it won't go up or down much either, it'll just stay right where it began. It might even get darker. But it won't get bigger. You, however, can. You can keep growing, doing more things, more branches, being more things. The wound won't get smaller but you can make it a smaller part of who you are. Maybe regrets are like that. They stick around forever like arborglyphs. Or maybe they make like a tree and leaf. A red or purple leaf in the autumn. As days get shorter and chlorophyll production decreases, the yellow and orange carotenoids, which are always in leaves, appear as the green fades. But red and purple leaves are the interesting ones. As winter approaches it would seem to be a good time for trees to conserve energy but some trees do the opposite. Instead of giving up, they spend extra energy producing anthocyanins to turn their leaves red and purple hues. These colors protect their leaves from sun damage before their nutrients can all be used and may also be a defense against insects looking for a parasitic home. A way for the tree to tell the insects: "Yes, I am in part dying but not without a fight. I am still very much vital." Drought and even tourniquets applied by man can bring about these colors prematurely. When you look at beautiful autumn colors, you are looking at stress. But the bigger the fight the trees put up, the more energy they put into their defenses at the very end, the more brilliant their colors will be. Winter will eventually come. But scientifically, the brightest, deepest, most remarkable colors come from not giving up too easily or quickly. And as always, thanks for watching.

The German he allowed to live was this man. Later the man whose life he spared wore his mustache shorter but still had the same name, Adolf Hitler. In 1918 did Henry Tandey miss a chance to kill Hitler? Detailed researchers found that the exact days their units were in the same location don't quite match up. The story is apocryphal but what is known is that Hitler owned a copy of the painting of Tandey, and in 1938, when meeting with Neville Chamberlain, Hitler pointed to Tandey and told Chamberlain: "That man came so close to killing me in 1918 that I thought I should never see Germany again." So, who's wrong? Maybe Hitler confirmed the story merely because he hoped to make up extra evidence that providence had kept him alive to pursue his goals. Either way, someone is mistaken. Missed opportunities are a bummer. Obsessing over them is not healthy but regret is a powerful emotion. How do you deal with regret, with guilt? Can you? In the early morning hours on a bench outside a hotel in Anaheim this summer Ze Frank told me something I am going to paraphrase. I love this metaphor. Stuff in your past is like a carving on the bark of sapling. Over time, the scar, the carving won't go away. Because of the way trees grow it won't go up or down much either, it'll just stay right where it began. It might even get darker. But it won't get bigger. You, however, can. You can keep growing, doing more things, more branches, being more things. The wound won't get smaller but you can make it a smaller part of who you are. Maybe regrets are like that. They stick around forever like arborglyphs. Or maybe they make like a tree and leaf. A red or purple leaf in the autumn. As days get shorter and chlorophyll production decreases, the yellow and orange carotenoids, which are always in leaves, appear as the green fades. But red and purple leaves are the interesting ones. As winter approaches it would seem to be a good time for trees to conserve energy but some trees do the opposite. Instead of giving up, they spend extra energy producing anthocyanins to turn their leaves red and purple hues. These colors protect their leaves from sun damage before their nutrients can all be used and may also be a defense against insects looking for a parasitic home. A way for the tree to tell the insects: "Yes, I am in part dying but not without a fight. I am still very much vital." Drought and even tourniquets applied by man can bring about these colors prematurely. When you look at beautiful autumn colors, you are looking at stress. But the bigger the fight the trees put up, the more energy they put into their defenses at the very end, the more brilliant their colors will be. Winter will eventually come. But scientifically, the brightest, deepest, most remarkable colors come from not giving up too easily or quickly. And as always, thanks for watching. cool huh.

Hey, Vsauce. Michael here. The title of this video is misspelled in honor of mistakes. Mistakes are everywhere, they surround us like air. To err is human. Faults, flaws, faux pas, fumbles and fallacies are as much a part of who we are today as the stuff we've gotten right. For instance, if a knight knocked your knuckle or knifed your knee, why would there be so many "k"s? Well, the "k"s are silent by mistake. The original old English forms of these words were pronounced with "k" sounds. K-nife, k-night, k-nee. But that's a bit of a mouthful to say and because reading and writing weren't as common hundreds of years ago, people just pronounced words the way they want to do, regardless of spelling. Spelling is fun. Warren G knows what I'm talking about. In the fourth verse of his "What's Next", he asks what's next. What's next, what's N-X-E-T. Spelling isn't the only thing we get wrong. The history of science is a graveyard of dead an abandoned ideas. Fritz Machlup coined the phrase "Half-life of knowledge". The amount of time it takes for half of the knowledge within a field to be superseded by new, better ideas or to simply be shown untrue. Donald Hebb famously estimated that the half-life of knowledge in psychology is just five years. Humans are awesome, don't get me wrong, but we tend to believe that what we currently think we know about the universe is reasonably correct, even though statistics aren't on our side. Previous generations incorrectly thought the exact same thing about what they used to think was true. My favorite examples of the ubiquity of mistakes are production errors in popular songs. They're like humbling Easter eggs, just waiting to be found. For instance, Buffalo Springfield's "For What It's Worth". 26 seconds in the "be" in the lyric "beware" is clipped, as is the "p" in "people" at 1:24 minute. Once you hear the mistake, it's tough to unhear it. In "Hey Jude" Paul McCartney misses a chord. And if you listen closely you can clearly hear him say "F**ing hll". Seriously, it's in the actual song. Go listen to it. In fact, there's an entire website that chronicles mistakes in Beatles' songs. Take a look at this 700-year-old prayer book. A monk wrote it on fresh, clean paper. I'm kidding, of course. He scraped the ink off an older manuscript, cut the pages and rotated them before writing all over them. A mistake? Well, kind of. Recent multispectral images of the prayer book have revealed that the old manuscript he erased was a previously unknown copy of a work by Archimedes. It was called "The Method" and laid out the heart of calculus thousands of years before Newton and Leibniz. If that one monk hadn't erased that one book, would we be hundreds, thousands of years mathematically and technologically more advanced today than we currently are? It's hard to say. All that is certain is that we would continue to make ridiculous mistakes, like the Mars Climate Orbiter. This 327.6 million dollar expedition burned up in the red planet's atmosphere because when calculating flight maneuvers NASA used the agreed-upon metric units while Lockheed Martin used the imperial system. This is Neil Armstrong taking humankind's first steps on the Moon. It's about the best footage we have. The original tapes containing the highest quality recording of that moment have been lost. They were probably recorded over by later test missions. Ten years ago Sergio Martinez became lost in the woods while hunting outside of San Diego. Hoping to attract the attention of rescuers, he lit a small fire. But that fire quickly got out of control and became a giant Cedar Fire. It destroyed 300,000 acres of land, 2,322 homes and killed 15 people. The man carrying a wounded soldier in this painting, based on a photograph taken during World War I, is Henry Tandey, an English recipient of the Victoria Cross. Four years after the event in this image Tandey caught a wounded German soldier in his gun sights. But rather than kill the man, Tandey took pity on his wounded state and spared his life. The German he allowed to live was this man. Later the man whose life he spared wore his mustache shorter but still had the same name, Adolf Hitler. In 1918 did Henry Tandey miss a chance to kill Hitler? Detailed researchers found that the exact days their units were in the same location don't quite match up. The story is apocryphal but what is known is that Hitler owned a copy of the painting of Tandey, and in 1938, when meeting with Neville Chamberlain, Hitler pointed to Tandey and told Chamberlain: "That man came so close to killing me in 1918 that I thought I should never see Germany again." So, who's wrong? Maybe Hitler confirmed the story merely because he hoped to make up extra evidence that providence had kept him alive to pursue his goals. Either way, someone is mistaken. Missed opportunities are a bummer. Obsessing over them is not healthy but regret is a powerful emotion. How do you deal with regret, with guilt? Can you? In the early morning hours on a bench outside a hotel in Anaheim this summer Ze Frank told me something I am going to paraphrase. I love this metaphor. Stuff in your past is like a carving on the bark of sapling. Over time, the scar, the carving won't go away. Because of the way trees grow it won't go up or down much either, it'll just stay right where it began. It might even get darker. But it won't get bigger. You, however, can. You can keep growing, doing more things, more branches, being more things. The wound won't get smaller but you can make it a smaller part of who you are. Maybe regrets are like that. They stick around forever like arborglyphs. Or maybe they make like a tree and leaf. A red or purple leaf in the autumn. As days get shorter and chlorophyll production decreases, the yellow and orange carotenoids, which are always in leaves, appear as the green fades. But red and purple leaves are the interesting ones. As winter approaches it would seem to be a good time for trees to conserve energy but some trees do the opposite. Instead of giving up, they spend extra energy producing anthocyanins to turn their leaves red and purple hues. These colors protect their leaves from sun damage before their nutrients can all be used and may also be a defense against insects looking for a parasitic home. A way for the tree to tell the insects: "Yes, I am in part dying but not without a fight. I am still very much vital." Drought and even tourniquets applied by man can bring about these colors prematurely. When you look at beautiful autumn colors, you are looking at stress. But the bigger the fight the trees put up, the more energy they put into their defenses at the very end, the more brilliant their colors will be. Winter will eventually come. But scientifically, the brightest, deepest, most remarkable colors come from not giving up too easily or quickly. And as always, thanks for watching.

Because of the way trees grow it won't go up or down much either, it'll just stay right where it began. It might even get darker. But it won't get bigger. You, however, can. You can keep growing, doing more things, more branches, being more things. The wound won't get smaller but you can make it a smaller part of who you are. Maybe regrets are like that. They stick around forever like arborglyphs. Or maybe they make like a tree and leaf. A red or purple leaf in the autumn. As days get shorter and chlorophyll production decreases, the yellow and orange carotenoids, which are always in leaves, appear as the green fades. But red and purple leaves are the interesting ones. As winter approaches it would seem to be a good time for trees to conserve energy but some trees do the opposite. Instead of giving up, they spend extra energy producing anthocyanins to turn their leaves red and purple hues. These colors protect their leaves from sun damage before their nutrients can all be used and may also be a defense against insects looking for a parasitic home. A way for the tree to tell the insects: "Yes, I am in part dying but not without a fight. I am still very much vital." Drought and even tourniquets applied by man can bring about these colors prematurely. When you look at beautiful autumn colors, you are looking at stress. But the bigger the fight the trees put up, the more energy they put into their defenses at the very end, the more brilliant their colors will be. Winter will eventually come. But scientifically, the brightest, deepest, most remarkable colors come from not giving up too easily or quickly. And as always, thanks for watching

Hitler incident: (Wikipedia)
Although disputed, Adolf Hitler and Tandey allegedly encountered each other at the French village of Marcoing. The story is set on 28 September 1918, while Tandey was serving with the 5th Duke of Wellington's Regiment, and relates that a weary German soldier wandered into Tandey's line of fire. The enemy soldier was wounded and did not even attempt to raise his own rifle. Tandey chose not to shoot. The German soldier saw him lower his rifle and nodded his thanks before wandering off. That soldier is purported to have been Adolf Hitler.[8][9][10] The author David Johnson, who wrote a book on Henry Tandey,[11] believes this story was an urban legend.

Fun fact:
Dutch is often considered to be the language that cognates the most with/to English, or at least the most similar.

All the words listed in the beginning of the video that are written with kn-:
Knight, knocked, knuckle, knife, knee
Their Dutch equivalents are knecht, knokte, knokkel, knijp and knie.
All of these are still being pronounced with a kn- sound in Dutch, and when done the same in English, they sound much more alike

I don't know if you can say that the man saving Hitler was a "mistake."  To do so means you have to take a deterministic view of the universe (not in the sense of quantum mechanics but rather that people are fated to fulfill certain roles).  And it also means you have to hold a consequentialist view.  It's easy to say, but most people are not willing to run an innocent person down with their car to save three... and many people won't condone it either.  On the other end is something like Batman, who continues to deliver the Joker safely to prison despite all the bad he might do, because there is no virtue in killing a man.  That soldier knew he was saving a German, who even then may have killed his own countrymen or may do so later, but he saved him regardless because he couldn't take away a man's future without the immediate need to do so.

OH MY! Michael you missed a HUGE mistake and you were so darn close to it! You pointed out the tapes from Neil Armstrong's first steps on the moon but jumped right over the biggest mistake of that audio recording! Neil Armstrong had pre-planned and rehearsed his quick speech "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for man kind." Except if you think about it, in that context, it makes no sense. "Man" just being a shortened way of saying "mankind" because he says "one small step for man" implying the entirety of mankind. What he meant to say, and had planned to say, but at the last moment screwed up, was "That's one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind."
Inspiring!

I really don't like the part about Hitler.
As if the good thing to do would have been to kill the man prior his deeds...
Killing someone that will otherwise kill millions of others seems logical.
But killing someone is not moral in the first place. You may have your reasons to do so (self defense) but it is a necessary evil. Necessary, alright. But still evil.
Moreover killing someone, the "Minority Report way", that is before he did what he is worth been killed for, is ethically wrong.
And if you believe the world is non deterministic, the Minority Report way doesn't make any sense.
So, at best, this situation is a catch 22 but in no circumstances is it an objective mistake.

i once commented under a video (cant remember where, or what it was about) that, how do you know object X is made out of XXX atoms? has anyone ever counted each single one of them? boy did people get angry with me! the very first reply was full of insults about how stupid one person has to be to ask such a question, when we CLEARLY have formulas that tell us the answer... im glad people like that arent responsible for our scientific and technological advance. while yes, those formulas currently are our best answer to our endless questions about the universe... the emphasis lies on "currently". not that long ago people thought the earth was a disk. not long ago people didnt know how bad smoking is for them. knowledge is always limited by the time you live in... no one ever knows for sure, what he knows. facts may and probably will change at some point in the future. new discoveries will lead to new conclusions, making the brightest minds of our time look like idiots. just as we, today, think that someone who seriously believs the earth is a disk must have been an idiot.

but theres nothing we can do about it. the knowledge we have, and we can gain right now is all weve got... for now we have to assume that what we know is correct, but as this video already stated... history has shown us that in most cases, we're actually wrong. all im trying to say is... no one should ever be satisfied with his knowledge, for it is most likely a mistake. go with what you have... but never assume that its the only possible and one, true answer to your question. if all people thought like that, we'd still be trying to figure out how to invent the wheel.

It's pretty cute how this idea of killing Hitler is floating around. Implying, of course, that killing him would absolutely change the course of history. But it so happens that history is not built around CHARACTERS. Well, not as much as we tend to believe. Rather, it is built around PRINCIPLES, TENDENCIES, and CONTEXTS. A country with deep economic troubles, hyperinflation, and lots of resentment, is almost certain to produce a dictator. And dictatorship is almost certain to rely on finding internal and external "enemies" to justify the current troubles.

My point is: even if, by some super-dooper-lucky chance Hitler had been killed, there were plenty of people to replace him in that political context. Just look at Hitler's immediate surrounding. 

And have you considered the possibility that we might, in fact, be extremely lucky? That someone, a person who could have become an even more terrifying figure in history, more talented and successful leader than Hitler, a person who could have won WW II for Nazi Germany, was actually killed in WW I? And Hitler was, if you please, only a second "best"? How about this?

I don't appreciate when people say that Archimedes created "calculus." Yes, he created various methods of quadrature, but nothing on the level of sophistication or systemics that Newton and Leibniz developed. His methods were probably interesting, but what is lost is that just having calculus doesn't make you more advanced and doesn't give you the tools to necessarily advance yourself. Maybe is his quadrature and Heron's Engine were considered together, there might have been an advance. But one event does not lead to a leap in human being. Calculus helped us understand the heavens, but it took further developments to understand thermodynamics, electrodynamics, continuum dynamics, etc. and how to apply what we learned. Archimedes was brilliant, but I doubt his pseudo-development of "calculus" would have changed the world.

That's a completely opposite explanation to anything I've been taught before for autumnal colouration of leaves. My understanding was that the chemicals causing red and yellow colouration in leaves were always there but hidden within the overall green appearance of those leaves, but when deciduous trees start to SAVE energy in response to colder weather by stopping production of chlorophyll to slow most of it's normal biological processes, then the decreasing amounts of chlorophyll mean the green colour slowly fades to reveal the red and yellow colouration that was hidden there all along. But what Mr Vsauce seems to be saying is that these trees actually SPEND energy producing additional red/yellow colouration to overpower and mask the normal green colouring.

OK, I can't take this anymore. I thought lots of other people would see the same thing that I see, but apparently I just see it. To show what I mean, pause the video and look carefully at Michael's face during these moments: 0:25, 0:56, 1:21,1:37,1:46 to 1:57, 3:10, 3:31, 3:37 to 3:47, 4:18 to 4:26, 6:09, 6:26, 8:40, 8:55, and 9:02 to 9:08. 

Maybe it's just me, but during those times, he looks extremely depressed or sad, and it's been bothering me and worrying me at the same time. The first time I noticed it was when Michael made that expression A LOT during the "SPACE STRAW" video, and I re-watched a couple recent videos, and he also had that expression a lot. Also, you know how Michael has been taking ridiculously long breaks? 

EVERYTHING FOLLOWING IS SPECULATION ONLY

Remember when Vsauce's video breaks were only a few days? As most of us know now, it normally takes WEEKS before another video was posted. If one of you comes up with the argument saying "he's making cooler and longer videos", he's managed to make "cooler and longer" videos in less than half the time of the break time for this video to finally be uploaded.

This video took three weeks to upload, which makes me, and a couple others, feel worried. I am not sure what happened to Vsauce and why he's been acting like this so much, but what if something happened where Michael was too caught up in it to make videos in enough time? Of course, I don't have any say in it, but I'm just speculating. 

Vsauce, if you see this comment, I really think you should answer these questions in a video. If not, at least take this into mind. Sooner or later, he'll have to explain why breaks between videos have been taking so long, because he'll be barraged with these questions. Hope you guys can understand what I mean.

Many games also have big Mistakes.

Zelda no Densetsu: The intro screen reads:
Many years ago Prince Darkness " Gannon " stole one of the triforce with power.
Princess Zelda had one of the triforce with wisdom. She divided it into " 8 " units to hide it from " Gannon " Before she was captured.
Go find the " 8 " Units " Link " to save her.

But it should read:

Many years ago Prince OF Darkness " Gannon " stole the Triforce OF Power
Princess Zelda had the Triforce OF Wisdom. She divided it into " 8 " units to hide it from " Gannon " Before she was captured.
Go find the " 8 " Units " Link " to save her.

Zelda 2: Rinku no Boken also has an error. Anyone who's played it remembers Error and Bagu, funny thing is, Bagu's name is wrong. In the Famicom version they were Era and Bagu translating as Error and Bug but mistranslations in the english version led to Error and Bagu.

Metroid: The Gender of Samus wasen't realized late into development. In the game Samus was a girl, but the manual was made before such choice was made refering to samus as a man.

Skyrim: In the mission "From deepest Fathoms" there's a sequence of how one of the charaters escaped the ordeal that the quest revolves around, the funny thing is it never plays ingame because of a spelling error in the sequence's name.

Left 4 Dead: Originally there was to be a romance between the character's Zoey and Francis, this was mostly removed except for two audio lines that can be heard in-game.

Pokemon Yellow\Red\Blue\Green: there's a hidden Safari Zone in the game, you can get to it via cheats, but you kinda can't because there's two adjacent fountains blocking the entrance.

The Henry Tandey story I always thought was interesting but: do you really think that if he actually shot Hitler, WWII wouldn't have started?  Hitler was a product of his surroundings/era and it's not like he was the only person who was anti-Semitic in Europe (See the Dreyfus Affair for instance) or the only "German" who wanted to lash out against barriers set up for the young German state by the Treaty of Versailles.  In a way the world was possibly lucky to have someone who was as incompetent of a military leader as Hitler because imagine if it was someone who was actually more competent and didn't fight a war on both sides.  And there is a belief in some historical circles that WWII actually stopped the territory expansion of Soviet Russia and the Cold War might have turned out differently. We may never know if it was a mistake or not because we were given the lot we were given.  That's my two cents.

I don't agree that the pronunciation of "knee" is an example of a mistake. It is simply an example of how the pronunciation of words in any language evolves over time. The way we say words today is different in many ways from the common pronunciations of, say, 15th century English speakers. One of the forms that this evolution takes is to simplify so as to make the words easier and quicker to say. Something that might be classed as a mistake is "juncture loss", such as when a certain hard green fruit was known as "a napple" and people mistakenly thought they were hearing "an apple".

To comment on your paraphrase:

Mistakes and thus the memories of the mistake do infact branch out, as in neurons laying new neuron connections.
The more connections the more powerfull the memory.
So yes, the memory of the mistake can get bigger and grow.
However, only IF YOU LET IT TO.
If you dont seek avoidance from either work, hobbies or any other activity you are more potent to keep remembering these mistakes making them more powerfull each time you think about it.
Amazingly this is also the exact same effect as an addiction or a "psychosis".

So yeah, the scar will not get bigger or smaller, however the memory of it can. But only if you let it to.

For all the people who might have these problems, everytime you think about a mistake, make sure you start doing something pretty soon cinema, out for dinner, date a girl, take a hike, fly a plane, become an astronaut or crashland a plane dressed as an astronaut in GTA V. Becouse before you know it youll keep thinking about it making it harder and harder to fight off (and again: like an addiction).

I don't want anyone to hate me for saying this, but me and my brother were having a conversation about killing Hitler in the car. I was saying how Hitler is a horrible disgusting man who had NO RIGHT to kill any of the Jews or Blacks, and my brother agreed with me. However, he then brought up the point that if before Hitler was born, racism still existed. 

Most people before this time (including several newspapers) were racist, and often judged people by colour or culture. When Hitler started the war and began killing all the Jews and Blacks, everyone started thinking,
 "This is extreme, maybe we should stop all of this racism and violence, it's wrong to judge people like this!" and we fought back. After Britain and there allies had won the war, racism was a no where near as bad as it was.

Maybe if Hitler hadn't started this war and done all these horrific things, we would still be having that problem today, as after the second World War, we had learnt our lesson about something very important...violence, racism, prejudice. In a way, Hitler saved us from a horrible future. After all, I'd rather live in a place where somebody did horrible things in the past, than a place where it is all still happening in the present.

Before I finish this comment I would like to bring up that I know Hitler was a HORRIBLE man and I CERTAINLY do NOT agree with what he did IN ANY WAY. I think what he did was wrong, and I am glad he has died now and that he lost the war. But if I had the choice to go back in time and kill Hitler, I wouldn't, as it might mess with now and continue all that horrific things that went on.

Again...please don't hate.

The "B" and "P" mistakes in "For What It's Worth" are most probably not mistakes but actually intentional. When recording vocals "B" and "P" sounds can make a popping sound when recorded. This popping effect can be reduced by something called a pop shield which is put in front of a microphone when recording vocals (it helps break up the blast of air that is caused by creating these particular sounds). Unfortunately even then the effect can still be quite audible. The raw vocals in this particular track probably had big "pops" in those particular spots and were therefore edited out because that sounded better then load pops in the mix. In 1966 recordings were analog so editing was very much limited. Now a days in digital recording you can zoom right into the sound wave and remove popping “B” and “P” sounds in a vocal take without cutting off the too much off the effected lyric, and therefore no one hears the edit in the mix.

The problem with the statistical argument for how wrong we might be as far as science goes is that there must necessarily be an end point where the things we have proven can not be disproved simply because they are actually correct. A good example would be the understanding that the sun is larger than the earth. That seems as incontrovertible a fact as any fact could be. It will never be incorrect to say that our sun is larger than our earth. The same thing could conceivably eventually be said about many scientific ideas that we now only see as unproven hypothesis or even theories that are not as obvious at the size difference between the sun and the earth.

the k-n sound is a bit of a mouthful to say... in English. You should've added that. Other languages who also have derivatives of these saxon words, still pronounce the k. In Norwegian for example we have kniv (knife), kne (knee), knoke (knuckle), and I suppose knekt can be used for knight (it's from the same root, but the meaning in Norwegian has changed a bit). And they are not mouthfuls to someone whose first language is Norwegian. But I can see how they would be if your first language is English.

Dammit, Tandey...

As another mistake, in Green Day's song "Good Riddance (Time of Your Life)" the original track off the Nimrod album, Billie Joe messes up a string or something and says "F**k!" And then continues to play the intro. I noticed this a few years ago when i was learning how to play the song on guitar myself.

I think a "Mistake" is being wrong when you shouldn't be. For example, getting a math problem on a test wrong when you were taught in class on how to do it properly is a mistake. Paul McCartney's missed chord is also a mistake.
Being "Wrong" is just that. Ancient people who believed the earth was flat weren't mistaken, they were wrong. They had no reason to believe otherwise. Henry Tandy showing mercy to Adolf Hitler wasn't a "Mistake". How should he have known, being merciful is always the right decision when you have no other information to go by.

Some people seem to forget that just because what we know now might be shown to be untrue doesn't mean that what has already been shown to be false suddenly becomes true again.

Also, nothing can contradict the facts that we've already gathered unless you can show the instruments were faulty (i.e., Jupiter cannot be said to not exist unless you can explain how all those space probes and telescopes can be mistaken).

I do have a question for MICHAEL about climate change: it seems to me that we have had average temperatures around the globe rising as we progress through our time. We also continue to drill and take oil out of the ground in various different ways. We do use oil as a lubricant as well as a  heat disbursement in various applications around the world. Couldn't a correlation be made between our draining the Earth's crust of a natural lubricant (oil) and the rising of temperatures - as well as other climate change. We do feel the heat that rises from the ground after warming from the Sun, correct? I will admit I did not research at all before asking my question... But it feels like a valid question. I feel as though as we drain the Earth of the oil separating our feet from the Earth's core, the Earth beneath us is getting hotter, which of course could contribute to rising temperatures around the world - since it would take less energy from the Sun to heat the ground. Would this be a valid talking point?

Totally an Olan Rogers outro there. Love it. This is very inspiring. I've been struggling lately with the concept of regret. I've made some decisions in my life that have had lasting and perhaps superficially undesirable effects on my life. But I've always taught myself to not regret, no matter how extreme the mistake may be and allow those mistakes to be a growing point and a lesson. At my current point in my life I'm pretty low and the culmination of all the mistakes I've made has left me in a very regrettable position. But I choose not to regret and instead I move forward and realize that things can only get better from this point (even though I know that may not necessarily be true). I choose to learn from my mistakes.

I love the illustration you made about the tree growing beyond it's scar. The mistakes make you who you are and give you character but they only bring you down if you let them, it's all about perspective. Mistakes are truly the greatest lesson, it's the fundamental method of how we as humans learn and grow. It's up to us to see the lesson and learn from it and not cower in the fear of making more mistakes.

The so called "mistake" in the Buffalo Springfield song may actually have been done on purpose. During lyrics with that plosive sound, sometimes the artist blows too much air over the mic causing a loud and unpleasant sound. The audio engineer cuts the beginning of the word out to get rid of that sound, but it goes unnoticed because our brilliant minds fill in the missing information automatically.

At the end of that video we were told that we humans have the illusion of choice. This means we think we are given as much control as we believe when reality we can't control it all. What we want to control is really something that was meant to be from the very start. So there's no point of trying to change what we obviously can't change. But at the end of THIS video the message is to never give up, for we can make the most colorful path and become something if we just keep pursuing our goals

I understand that we can't control everything, like death or the stock market. We don't have that much control when it comes to systems that are already set in motion, but why should we never give up and keep on pursuing if we can't even predict the future we want?
